BC-FBN-GIANTS-NYT 
RUNNING BACK JOHNSON TO BE TREATED FOR CANCER 

   (ja)  
 By BILL PENNINGTON   
 c.1998 N.Y. Times News Service  
 

   NEW YORK _ Wednesday morning at Giants Stadium, Giants Coach Jim
Fassel gathered his players around him as he always does at the
conclusion of practice, but on this occasion, Fassel did not
discuss football.

   With most players on one knee, Fassel led the team in prayer for
running back LeShon Johnson, a recent free-agent acquisition, who
Wednesday received a diagnosis of lymphoma, a form of cancer. Team
doctors detected an abnormality after a routine chest X-ray last
month and, in subsequent tests, determined that Johnson, 27, had a
cancerous tumor.

   The Giants declined to reveal the course of treatment Johnson
would receive in the coming weeks, but team officials said
privately that the preliminary opinion of Johnson's doctors was
that he would receive radiation treatments and that the prognosis
for a full recovery was good. He is not expected to have surgery. A
team doctor added that the cancer was discovered at an early stage.

   ``My doctors tell me we have a good chance to cure this,''
Johnson said in a statement released by the team. ``My family and I
believe that with the help of the doctors and with the strength of
our faith in God, we will get through this and I will be back on
the field in 1998.''

   Johnson signed a free-agent contract with the Giants on March 10
and worked out regularly at Giants Stadium thereafter. There were
no symptoms of his cancer, Fassel said. Johnson participated fully
in the three-day minicamp May 4-6, a week after he had been
married. He and his wife, Nalani, have a 5-month-old son.

   Johnson, the team noted Wednesday, had a chest X-ray last year
as a member of the Arizona Cardinals.

   ``There was nothing unusual on that X-ray then,'' Giants General
Manager Ernie Accorsi said. ``The doctors have told us they are
optimistic they can contain this.''

   Johnson will be treated by Dr. David Wolf, a hematology
oncologist at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

   Giants coaches and executives were reluctant to answer questions
about Johnson's football future.

   ``Our concern is his health and that he gets the best possible
treatment,'' said Fassel, who coached Johnson in 1996 when he was
the offensive coordinator in Arizona.

   Other team officials who asked not to be identified said that
while Johnson's chances of a full recovery were excellent, it
appeared unlikely that he would return to play this season.

   In August 1987, Karl Nelson was a star offensive lineman for the
Giants when he received a diagnosis of Hodgkin's disease, a type of
lymphoma. He missed the 1987 season and returned to play in 1988
before there was a recurrence of his cancer. Free of the disease
since 1989, Nelson retired to a career as a broadcaster and
insurance executive.

   The Giants have contacted Nelson, who was also treated by Wolf,
to enlist his aid in Johnson's treatment and recovery. ``I talk to
a lot of people who are going through this,'' Nelson said
Wednesday. ``The important thing for LeShon is that he stay
mentally tough and positive. Generally, athletes can do that
better. They are used to fighting through things _ dealing with
things when you are physically and mentally tired.''

   Although Johnson has been with the team fewer than three months,
he becomes the fifth active Giants player to have cancer in the
last 18 years. Dan Lloyd, a linebacker, had lymphatic cancer in
1980 and recovered. Running back Doug Kotar died in 1983 of a brain
tumor. John Tuggle, also a running back, died of cancer in 1986.

   After Tuggle's death, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition
Authority financed a study of the Meadowlands complex and nearly
10,000 current and former employees there. The study found there
was no conclusive link between the Giants Stadium environment and
cancer.

   ``I'm sure that's one of the first things people said,'' Nelson
said. ``The Giants and cancer. But LeShon just got here.''

   When the team convened this week for a passing camp at Giants
Stadium, Johnson attended but was not in uniform as he awaited the
results of a biopsy. Fassel told reporters that Johnson wasn't
feeling well, unwilling to say more until there was a more
definitive diagnosis.

   ``LeShon was in excellent spirits,'' said Jim Skipper, the
offensive coordinator, who also coached Johnson as an assistant in
Arizona. ``He came to all our meetings and asked questions. He
acted the same. His nature is to be positive, which should be a
major plus for him.''

   Johnson, who is 6 feet and 207 pounds, played with the Cardinals
for parts of three seasons, leading the team with 634 rushing yards
in 1996. The Giants signed Johnson to add speed to a deep backfield
that includes Charles Way, Tyrone Wheatley, Tiki Barber and Gary
Brown.
